revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''The 2009 Latvian meteorite hoax''' was a [[publicity stunt]] in which [[Sweden|Swedish]]-based telecommunications company [[Tele2]] staged an apparent [[meteorite]] landing which was later revealed to be fake.
==The "Meteorite" incident== The drama began at around 17:30 local time (15:30 [[GMT]]) in [[Latvia]] on Sunday 25 October 2009.<ref name ="BBC">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8326483.stm|title=Doubts over Latvia "meteor crash"|work=[[BBC News]]|date=26 October 2009 <!-- (18:18GMT) --> |accessdate=2 November 2009 }}</ref> Student Ancis Steinbergs reported that a fiery [[meteor]]-like object had fallen in a field outside the town of [[Mazsalaca]] near the [[Estonia]]n border.<ref name ="Times"/><ref name ="Local">{{Cite news|last=Landes|first=David|url=http://www.thelocal.se/22910/20091027/|title=Swedish telecoms firm admits to Latvia meteorite hoax|work=The Local|date=27 October 2009|accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> Reports described the object lighting up the evening sky with a blazing trail<ref name = "Local"/><ref name="Space1">{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/BUSINESS/10/27/latvia.fake.meteor.ft/ |title=Earlier related report |work=[[Spacedaily.com|Space Daily]] |date=26 October 2009 |accessdate=2 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101093547/http://edition.cnn.com/2009/BUSINESS/10/27/latvia.fake.meteor.ft/ |archivedate=1 November 2009 }}</ref> and hitting the ground with a loud crash,<ref name ="Local"/> leaving a burning [[Impact crater|crater]] claimed to be around {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide and from {{convert|3|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name ="AHN">{{Cite news|last=Young|first=Linda| url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016801595?Meteor-Like%20Object%20Crashes%20Into%20Latvian%20Field%20Carving%20Out%20Large%20Crater|title=Meteor-Like Object Crashes Into Latvian Field Carving Out Large Crater|work=All Headline News|date=26 October 2009 <!-- (9:19am EST) -->|accessdate=2 November 2009}}</ref> up to {{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name="Times">{{Cite news|last=Halpin|first=Tony|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article6890838.ece|title='Meteorite' that landed in Latvia is a hoax, experts say|work=[[The Times]]|date=26 October 2009|accessdate=2 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> deep. Fire crews, police and military units attended the site, which was cordoned off while tests were carried out to check radiation levels.<ref name ="BBC"/> The crater quickly attracted scientific and media interest amid widespread speculation about the origin of the object.<ref name="Allnews">{{Cite news|last=Cohen |first=Michael |url=http://www.allnewsweb.com/page9299792.php |title=UFO crashes into Latvia creating massive crater and media frenzy, video |work=All News Web |date=26 October 2009 |accessdate=2 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027213757/http://www.allnewsweb.com/page9299792.php |archivedate=27 October 2009 }}</ref>
Steinbergs also filmed a video in which he and his two companions (his girlfriend and another student) approach the smoking crater and talk to each other excitedly when they apparently discover a burning mass at the bottom of the crater. The deliberately amateur style of the video, with shaky handheld camerawork and apparently spontaneous reactions from the students, has been compared to [[The Blair Witch Project]].<ref name ="Times"/> The video was published on [[YouTube]] and news websites,<ref name ="Allnews"/><ref name ="Sky"> {{Cite news | last=Rowley | first=Emma | url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Falling-Meteor-Blamed-For-15-Metre-Wide-Crater-In-Latvia/Article/200910415417869?f=rss | title=Splatvia! 'Meteor Crater' Was Really A Hoax | work=Sky News Online | date=27 October 2009 | accessdate=2 November 2009 }} </ref> attracting worldwide interest. Landowner Larisa Gerasimova reportedly charged visitors the equivalent of $2 each to view the crater.<ref name="Times"/>
==Investigation== The first scientist to visit the site, Uldis Nulle of the Latvian Environment, Geology and Meteorology Centre, said his initial impression was that a meteor impact could have caused the crater.<ref name="BBC"/> <ref name="AP"> {{Cite news | url=http://dsc.discovery.com/news/2009/10/26/meteorite-latvia.html | title=Latvian crater: meteorite or hoax? | work=[[The Associated Press]] | publisher=Discovery Channel News | date=26 October 2009 | accessdate=2 November 2009 }} </ref> However, when he later examined the site in daylight he concluded it had been faked.<ref name ="BBC"/> Other scientists who inspected the crater confirmed that it was a hoax. Andris Karpovics, a doctoral student of [[geology]] at the [[University of Latvia]], described the crater as "a simple, man-made hole with a substance poured in".<ref name ="CNN1"/> He told journalists that the hole appeared to have been dug with shovels, and noted that [[thermite]] (a mixture of [[aluminium]] and [[iron]], possibly with [[sulfur]] added), probably caused the increased temperatures observed in the crater.<ref name ="CNN1"/> The crater was considerably smaller than initially reported: its actual diameter was around {{convert|9|-|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} and it was about {{convert|2|-|3|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep.<ref name ="BBC"/><ref name ="Times"/> <ref name ="CNN1"> {{Cite news | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/10/26/latvia.meteorite/ | title=Experts doubt meteor led to Latvian crater | work=[[CNN]] | date=26 October 2009 <!-- (20:18 GMT) --> | accessdate=2 November 2009 }} </ref> Dr Ilgonis Vilks, chairman of the scientific council at the University of Latvia’s Institute of Astronomy, declared “it’s a fake. It’s very disappointing, I was full of hope coming here, but I am certain it is not a meteorite.”<ref name ="Times"/> Dr Vilks pointed out that there was green grass inside the artificial crater, with only a small area at the bottom burnt, and no ejected material or meteorite fragments were found on surrounding land. He described the supposed meteorite as "a ball of clay that was burning", and said that samples had been taken for university geologists to examine. He noted "There was a small blast heard by local people but this was not strong enough to create the crater".<ref name ="Times"/> Nature conservationist Dainis Ozols also examined the scene and said he believed that someone had burned a [[pyrotechnic]] compound at the bottom of a man-made hole to create the illusion of a meteorite crater.<ref name ="Times"/> Police warned of a possible criminal investigation into the hoax.<ref name = "AU"> {{Cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,,26266884-1702,00.html | title=Phone company sorry for Latvia meteorite hoax | work=[[news.com.au]] | date=27 October 2009 | accessdate=2 November 2009 }} </ref>
Caroline Smith, meteorite curator at the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]] in [[London]], stated that the pictures and video footage of the burning crater indicated that it was not a meteorite crater: meteorites are not aflame when they strike Earth.<ref name ="BBC"/> Smith also pointed out that there were no other reported sightings of any fireball in the sky,<ref name ="BBC"/> which would have been very clearly visible had the "meteorite" been real.<ref name ="BA"> {{Cite news | last=Plait | first=Phil | url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/10/26/latvian-meteorite-impact-fake/ | title=Latvian meteor impact: fake | work=Bad astronomy blog | publisher=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]] | date=26 October 2009 | accessdate=3 November 2009 }} </ref> It is believed that a meteorite would have to be around a metre or more in diameter to result in a crater of that size.<ref name ="BBC"/> Sizeable meteorites are rare, since most objects which enter the Earth's atmosphere burn up before reaching the planet's surface. The most recent large meteorite known to have landed on Earth [[Carancas impact event|struck near Carancas in Peru]] in 2007, leaving a crater around {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name ="BBC"/>
==Tele2's admission and aftermath== On Tuesday 27 October 2009, Swedish-based telecommunications company Tele2 admitted to perpetrating the hoax as a [[publicity stunt]], and promised to reimburse the Latvian government for expenses incurred in responding to the incident.<ref name ="Local"/> <ref name ="NYT"> {{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/10/27/world/AP-EU-Latvia-MeteoriteH.html?_r=1 | title=Mobile Phone Firm Behind Latvia Meteorite Hoax | work=[[The Associated Press]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=27 October 2009 | accessdate=3 November 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} </ref> Spokesperson Vita Sirica representing the Latvian branch of Tele2 said the stunt, which was organised in collaboration with media agency ''Inspired'', <ref name ="BC"> {{Cite news | last=Kolyako | first=Nina | url=http://www.baltic-course.com/eng/markets_and_companies/?doc=19850 | title=Association president: action with meteorite hoax could be considered an ethics violation in advertising | publisher=''The Baltic Course'' | date=28 October 2009 | accessdate=3 November 2009 }} </ref> was intended "to draw attention away from Latvia's economic crisis and toward something else more interesting."<ref name ="NYT"/> She explained that 9 people had dug the hole and burned chemicals at the bottom to create the elaborate hoax.<ref name ="NYT"/> The meteorite hoax occurred the day before the recession-hit Latvian government approved an [[austerity]] budget for 2010,<ref name="AU"/> and some officials were not impressed by the stunt. Interior Minister [[Linda Murniece]] accused Tele2 of a "cynical mockery", and announced that the Government would cancel its contract with Tele2, stating "The Interior Ministry doesn't want to do business with a firm that promotes itself at our expense".<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="FT">{{Cite news|last=Ward |first=Andrew |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/BUSINESS/10/27/latvia.fake.meteor.ft |title=Tele2 in a hole over 'meteor' publicity stunt |work=[[The Financial Times]] |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=28 October 2009 |accessdate=3 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091031024156/http://edition.cnn.com/2009/BUSINESS/10/27/latvia.fake.meteor.ft |archivedate=31 October 2009 }}</ref>
Pernilla Oldmark, spokesperson for Tele2 in [[Stockholm]], said the hoax had been carried out by the Latvian branch of Tele2 though authorised by its head office.<ref name ="NYT"/> She apologised for disruption and said the stunt had been intended to launch a forthcoming marketing campaign, claiming "The message will become clear as soon as the concept is launched".<ref name ="FT"/> Latvian Advertising Association President Girts Ozols said that the situation was unprecedented but the hoax could be considered an ethics violation in professional advertising.<ref name="BC"/> Ozols expressed concern that the incident had caused the community to feel insecure, and commented "If such a prank is pulled, the culprits should not have allowed it to drag on for so long without revealing the truth."<ref name="BC"/> The Latvian Advertising Association's board is to review the matter.<ref name="BC"/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:2009 Latvian Meteorite Hoax}} [[Category:Mazsalaca]] [[Category:2009 in Latvia|Latvian Meteorite Hoax, 2009]] [[Category:Hoaxes in Latvia]] [[Category:Hoaxes in Sweden]] [[Category:Hoaxes in science]]

revision.text:
{{use DMY dates|date=July 2015}}
'''Project Spade''', an international police investigation into [[child pornography]], began in October 2010 in [[Toronto|Toronto, Canada]]. The investigation started when [[Toronto Police Service]] officers made on-line contact with a man who was alleged to have been sharing pornographic videos via the [[Internet]] and by mail. The investigation eventually covered over 50 countries. Almost 350 people were arrested internationally, and 386 children were said to have been rescued.
== Investigation == Following numerous complaints received by the website [[cybertip.ca]] about Azov Films,<ref name=BBC-24944358>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-24944358 | work=BBC News | title=Hundreds held over Canada child porn |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=14 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> the investigation began in October 2010 when undercover police made online contact with Brian Way, a 42-year-old man from Toronto<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> and the owner of Toronto-based Azov Films, a firm that distributed DVDs and streaming videos of naked children which it marketed as "naturist."<ref name=BBC-24947579>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-24947579 | work=BBC News | title = Police hail success of Canada child porn investigation |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.azovfilms.com/legal.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227234544/http://www.azovfilms.com/legal.asp |archivedate=2010-12-27 |title=Web Archive copy of original Azov Films legal compliance statement |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2010-12-27 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref>
In May 2011 Way's home and office were raided, and he was arrested.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> Toronto law enforcement authorities and the [[U.S. Postal Inspection Service]] recreated Way's customer records and shared them with the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] and [[Interpol]]. Investigations involved more than 50 countries.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> Way is alleged to have earned more than $4 million from his website.<ref name=OzABC-5093498/>
Apart from Canada, Australia and the United States, authorities in Hong Kong, South Africa, Spain and Sweden were involved.<ref name=OzABC-5093498/> Investigations also spread to Greece, Ireland, New Zealand, Norway and Spain.<ref name=loncomnews421805>{{cite news| url=http://www.londoncommunitynews.com/news-story/4218805-four-london-men-arrested-in-child-porn-sting/ |title=Four London men arrested in child porn sting |publisher=Londoncommunitynews.com |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
The Canadian arm of the operation was "Project Spade", in Australia it was "Operation Thunderer".<ref name=OzABC-5093498/> Up to 45 [[terabytes]] of images and videos were seized.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/>
Inspector Joanna Beaven-Desjardins, of the TPS' Sex Crimes Unit, said, "It's a first for the magnitude of the victims saved" and "the amount of arrests internationally, also a first."<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> Beaven-Desjardins also spoke about materials seized from Way's home: "Officers located hundreds of thousands of images and videos detailing horrific sexual acts against very young children, some of the worst that they have ever viewed."<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> The materials distributed commercially by Azov Films featured nude athletic and recreational scenes, but not explicit sexual acts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/fweb/d/0B9hyw3-Boc65MU1ZSWNwMmlva00/edit?pli=1 |title=J.M. Wilson Motion to Suppress |publisher=Docs.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/docweb9612120/Phillip-Woolery-Filed-Complaint |title=P. Woolery Criminal Complaint, paragraphs 3-4 |publisher=Scribd.com |date=2012-10-10 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> The nudity-only nature of the Azov Films material caused it to be classified in the UK as level 1 on the [[COPINE scale]] for rating images of children, ''i.e.'', generally beneath the threshold of legal interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalcrimeagency.gov.uk/news/258-statement-on-ceop-s-involvement-in-project-spade |title="Statement on CEOP's involvement in Toronto Police's Project Spade," National Crime Agency, 15 Nov. 2013 |publisher=Nationalcrimeagency.gov.uk |date=2013-11-15 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> This standardized rating caused controversy, as politicians and members of the UK press later accused the [[National Crime Agency]] of negligence.<ref name=DM-2859681>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/national-crime-agency-police-finally-2859681 | work=Daily Mirror | title=Police finally investigating 2,345 suspected child abusers on Canadian detectives' list |last=Pettifor |first= Tom |date=28 November 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
The investigation was officially made public in November 2013.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/><ref name=USPIS-131113>{{cite press release| url=https://postalinspectors.uspis.gov/radDocs/PressRoom/nr131113.htm |title=International Child Exploitation Investigation Results In 339 Arrests, 386 Children Rescued | publisher=Postalinspectors.uspis.gov |date=13 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> Alternative news sources had disclosed its existence as early as December. 2012<ref name=DCFREEP-312201277>{{cite news|url=http://www.duboiscountyfreepress.com/child-porn-arrest-part-of-expansive-investigation-into-canadian-film-company/ | work=Dubois County Free Press | title=Child porn arrest part of expansive investigation into Canadian film company |last=Crane |first= Matthew |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
===Germany=== {{POV|date=February 2014}} The German [[Federal Criminal Police Office (Germany)|Federal Criminal Police Office]] was informed in October 2011, but investigations only started in October 2012,<!---had been ongoing since April 2013 but were reallocated to different authorities in different cities and to all 16 German states---> with the list of customers being distributed to the German states' authorities in November 2012.<ref name=TS>{{cite news |author=von Christian Tretbar |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/innenausschuss-zur-affaere-um-sebastian-edathy-bka-chef-ziercke-entlastet-oppermann/9504238.html |title=Oppermann im Innenausschuss: Tipp aus SPD-Spitze an Edathy "völlig abwegig" |language=de |publisher=Tagesspiegel.de |date=2014-02-19 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> During 13 months of holding back any investigations it should have been obvious for [[Federal Criminal Police Office (Germany)|Federal Criminal Police Office]] that within the list there were IP-numbers of Deutscher Bundestag with at least several downloads of nude material of boys of the age between 9 and 14 towards the German Bundestag IP-numbers range.<ref>{{cite news |author= |url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2014-02/edathy-vorwuerfe-reaktion |title=Kinderpornografie: Edathy will sich juristisch wehren |work=ZEIT ONLINE |publisher=Zeit.de |date=2014-02-15 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref>
Five hundred of the 800 listed persons had purchased unambiguous child pornography according to German legal standards; the rest had bought material not considered to be illegal.<ref name=TS/> A German [[MdB|MP]] appeared on the list; since the material he purchased wasn't categorized as clearly illegal, the case was held back pending further investigations, until February 10, 2014, when his house was raided.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.de/german-politician-edathy-rejects-child-porn-allegation/a-17423900 |title=German politician Edathy rejects child porn allegation |publisher=DW.DE |date=2014-11-02 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> According to Jörg Fröhlich, public prosecutor in Hannover, Lower Saxony, the raid took place for reason of a higher count of other public prosecutor agencies handling similar cases this way against the account of agencies favoring not to do so when found material would need to be categorized as so-called "II" instead of "I" .<ref>Jörg Fröhlich, head of Staatsanwalt Hannover in a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l8-O5uot-Yk&t=19m03s press conference on 14 February 2014], [[Phoenix (German TV station)|PHOENIX]] video on Youtube (German).</ref>{{better source|date=February 2014}} The passing of secret information regarding the investigation to the MP's party leader resulted in the resignation of the former German Interior Minister, [[Hans-Peter Friedrich]].
The home raid on Edathy when he had only purchased materials classified as legal was criticized in a national newspaper, ''Die Zeit'', in a guest editorial by Thomas Fischer, Chief Judge of the German Federal Court.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fischer |first=Thomas |date=6 March 2014 |title=Bitte entschuldigen Sie, Herr Edathy |trans-title=Please forgive us, Mr. Edathy |url=http://www.zeit.de/2014/10/staatsanwaltschaft-fall-edathy |language=German |newspaper=De Zeit |accessdate=23 March 2014 }}</ref> He stated, "Law exists in clear boundaries between permitted and forbidden behavior. Justice dares not follow he who does nothing illegal. In the Edathy case, this rule has been violated." In contrast, however, Mick Moran, head of Interpol's Human Trafficking and Child Exploitation unit, issued a public warning on Twitter to "MAPs" ("minor-attracted persons") that any sign they were acting upon their sexual orientations, whether the actions were legal or illegal, "demonstrates an escalation of activity by 'MAPs' that must be interpreted as an increased risk to children regardless of the illegality" and that "must result in action by public safety officials."
Public discussion about nude pictures of children being legal in Germany, when not categorized as sexual in nature, led within hours to a published consent from all parliamentary parties, as well as from Germany's Minister of Justice [[Heiko Maas]], for a prompt change of the relevant law.
On a February 19, 2014, a non-public meeting of the federal home affairs committee where BKA president [[Jörg Ziercke]] was reporting on this affair—Ziercke admitted, according to MP [[Wolfgang Bosbach|Bosbach]]—who leads that committee—towards reporters, that he had not seen any reason to publish the involved MP´s name any earlier, since at that time [[Sebastian Edathy]] was head of the [[Bosphorus serial murders|NSU-murderseries]] committee doing inquiries against the BKA and therefore himself, Ziercke, so to prevent the obviously wrong public image of a nonexisting act of revenge.<ref name="TS"/>
== Children == Apart from the children involved in the production of the Azov films, 386 children were said to have been rescued from exploitation by purchasers of the films. In Canada alone, 24 were rescued {citation needed- previous link lead to a 404} while six were rescued in Australia.<ref name=OzABC-5093498/> "More than 330 children"<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2013/11/14/child_porn_bust_anatomy_of_an_international_child_pornography_investigation.html |title=Child porn bust: Anatomy of an international child pornography investigation |work=Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2013-11-14 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> were stated to have been rescued in the US. This high number has been questioned, since full details of the charges for 54 of the total of 76 arrests in the US had been publicly released as of Nov. 14, 2013, and these details account for fewer than 15 persons exposed as children to current or historical sexual contact.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} An additional 75 to 100 children were surreptitiously indecently photographed, mostly by two arrested men who were school employees. The definition of "rescued child" used was that "the children were either being sexually abused or they were being sexually exploited by having videos taken of them in exploitative positions."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://voiceofrussia.com/web2013_11_18/International-sting-nets-pedophiles-frees-hundreds-of-kids-5447/ |title=International sting nets pedophiles, frees hundreds of kids |work=Voice of Russia interview with Det. Paul Krawczyk, 18 Nov., 2013 |publisher=Voiceofrussia.com |date=2013-11-18 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> The 'exploitative positions' always included nudity or genital exposure.
== Arrests == {{As of|2013|11|14}}, 348 people were arrested internationally. Those arrested included priests or pastors, teachers, foster parents, doctors and nurses. A police officer and a youth baseball coach were also arrested.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/><ref name=OzABC-5093498/> A Richmond, Virginia, man was sentenced to 70 months in prison on April 11, 2013, for receipt of child pornography.<ref name=USDOJ-20130412>{{cite press release| url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/vae/news/2013/04/20130412baynesnr.html | title=Richmond Man Sentenced To 70 Months For Receipt Of Child Pornography |publisher=USDOJ: US Attorney's Office - Eastern District of Virginia|date=12 April 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
In Canada alone 108 people were arrested.<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> In the US 76 were arrested.<ref name=dailymail2507459>{{cite news| author=Staff Reporter| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2507459/Global-child-porn-ring-busted-leading-rescue-nearly-400-children.html |title=76 Americans busted in massive global child porn ring including police officers, teachers and doctors as nearly 400 children are rescued |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=14 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> In Australia arrests began in August 2013 and 65 persons aged from 25 to 72 were arrested.<ref name=OzABC-5093498/> In Spain 28 were arrested in December 2012.<ref name=star2012-12-08>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2012/12/08/28_arrested_in_spain_for_alleged_link_to_torontobased_child_porn_network.html# |title=28 arrested in Spain for alleged link to Toronto-based child porn network |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2012-12-08 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref>
== Charges == Way has been charged with 24 offenses. The charges include "instruction of a criminal organisation" and "making, possessing, distributing and exporting [[child exploitation]] ... ", which had "explicit images of boys ranging in age from [[toddler]]s to [[teenager|teens]]."<ref name=ottawa-9163452/> Way's mother, Sandra Waslov, is still sought by authorities. Waslov changed her name on 5.21.2010 in Orchard Park, Erie County, New York.<ref name=ottawa-9163452>{{cite web|last=Mehta |first=Diana |url=http://www.ottawacitizen.com/news/Toronto+police+reveal+details+bust+international+child/9163452/story.html |title=Huge child porn ring busted, Toronto police say 348 arrested in Project Spade |publisher=Ottawacitizen.com |date=14 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref><ref>http://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcivil/FCASCaseInfo?parm=Motion&index=UJHp4jaBq1oLiCuy4KkN5w%3D%3D&county=kl849lYatoCk0lJr8iKrrw%3D%3D</ref>
The 65 Australian suspects face 399 charges involving child exploitation. The charges include " ... accessing, possessing, producing and distributing online child exploitation material".<ref name=OzABC-5093498>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-15/global-child-pornography-ring-smashed-by-canadian-and-australia/5093498 |title=66 Australians arrested as Canadian police smash 'horrific' child sex abuse ring - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
== Suicide of a US government official == One of the high-impact arrests resulting from Project Spade was that of [[Ryan Loskarn]]. The 35-year-old was chief of staff to U.S. Sen. [[Lamar Alexander]] at the time of his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accessnorthga.com/detail.php?n=268822 |title=GOP senator's staffer arrested on child porn charges |publisher=AccessNorthGa |date=2013-12-12 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref><ref>[http://kdal610.com/news/articles/2013/dec/16/us-senators-ex-top-aide-under-house-arrest-in-child-porn-case/ “GOP senator's staffer arrested on child porn charges”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419014630/http://kdal610.com/news/articles/2013/dec/16/us-senators-ex-top-aide-under-house-arrest-in-child-porn-case/ |date=19 April 2014 }}, 12 December 2013</ref> An investigation of Loskarn's electronic equipment was prompted in part by the appearance of his name on the Azov Films customer list. It uncovered graphic child pornography that had been obtained over the [[Gnutella]] peer-to-peer network<ref>[https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/895037/statement-of-facts-loskarn-case.pdf ‘Statement of Facts’ re Jesse Ryan Loskarn] Brian Bone, Postal Inspector, US Postal Inspection Service, 12 December 2013</ref> Loskarn was charged with possessing and intending to distribute child pornography and released on his own recognizance five days after his arrest on December 11, 2013.<ref name=TNN-312180185>{{cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/article/20131219/NEWS03/312180185 | work=The Tennessean | title= Indictment deadline extended in ex-Alexander aide's porn case |last=Roche Jr |first=Walter F. |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> On January 23, 2014, he committed suicide by hanging himself at his parents' home. In his suicide note, published on the internet by his family, he stated that "I found myself drawn to videos that matched my own childhood abuse."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/196346-senate-staffer-arrested-on-child-pornography-charges-found-dead |title=Senate staffer arrested on child pornography charges found dead |author=Rebecca Shabad |publisher=Thehill.com |date=2014-01-24 |accessdate=2014-03-28}}</ref> The incident provoked wide discussion in Washington, with [[Washington Post]] opinion writer Ruth Marcus suggesting that "we should use this sad episode to call attention to the need for mental health services--although Loskarn's problem was not lack of access but lack of willingness to accept the help available . . . But we should also use the moment to remind ourselves that reality is more complex than our cursory assumptions acknowledge, and that before we rush to condemn we might pause to consider the possibility of compassion."<ref name=WP-12a45d109e03>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/ruth-marcus-the-tragedy-of-ryan-loskarn/2014/02/06/e75d3dfe-8f46-11e3-b227-12a45d109e03_story.html | work=Washington Post | title=The tragedy of Ryan Loskarn|last=Marcus |first=Ruth |date=6 February 2014 |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref>
== Suicide of Martin Goldberg == Martin Goldberg, a deputy headteacher in [[Essex]], hanged himself after being investigated following information uncovered in Canada. Approximately 75 indecent images of children were found in his possession from his schools' changing rooms; 465 were taken at the swimming pools of his local leisure centre and 38 from other locations.<ref name=BBC11M>{{cite news|title=Southend teacher Martin Goldberg 'betrayed' school|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-essex-30623060|accessdate=23 July 2015|work=BBC News|date=29 December 2014|location=Essex, UK}}</ref>
The headteacher of the school that he worked at said that he felt "utter shock and betrayal" about Goldberg's behavior, which had been brought to the attention of [[Essex Police]] in 2013.<ref name=BBC11M />
== See also == * [[2007 international child pornography investigation]] * [[Operation Avalanche (child pornography investigation)]] – 1991 * [[Operation Delego]] – 2009

{{•}}'''Benghazi'''{{clarify|date=September 2011|reason=prose is unclear/vague, it seems, on this renaming date.}} |established_title3 = |established_date3 = |area_magnitude = |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = 314 |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |area_total_sq_mi = |area_land_sq_mi = |area_water_sq_mi = |area_water_percent = |area_urban_km2 = |area_urban_sq_mi = |area_metro_km2 = |area_metro_sq_mi = |area_blank1_title = |area_blank1_km2 = |area_blank1_sq_mi = |population_as_of = 2011 |population_footnotes = |population_note = |population_total = 631555 |population_density_km2 = auto |population_density_sq_mi = |population_metro = 1110000 |population_density_metro_km2 = |population_density_metro_sq_mi = |population_urban = |population_density_urban_km2 = |population_density_urban_sq_mi = |population_blank1_title =Ethnicities |population_blank1 = |population_blank2_title =Religions |population_blank2 = |population_density_blank1_km2 = |population_density_blank1_sq_mi = |population_demonym = Benghazian |timezone = [[Eastern European Time|EET]] |utc_offset = +2 |coordinates = {{coord|32|07|N|20|04|E|region:LY|display=inline}} |elevation_footnotes ={{cite web|url=http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Benghazi|title=Wolfram-Alpha: Computational Knowledge Engine|publisher=|accessdate=30 November 2016}} |elevation_m = 2 |elevation_ft = |postal_code_type = |postal_code = |area_code = (+218) 61 |blank_name = |blank_info = |blank1_name = |blank1_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Benghazi''' {{IPAc-en|b|ɛ|n|ˈ|ɡ|ɑː|z|i}}{{refn|{{lang-ar|بنغازي}}{{cite web|url=http://www.geographic.org/geographic_names/name_non-roman_benghazi_libya.html |title=بنغازي: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} {{transl|ar|Banġāzī}}, {{IPA-all|bənˈʁɑːzi|[[Libyan Arabic]]:|Ar-Banghazi.ogg}}; {{lang-it|Bengasi}}; {{lang-tr|Bingazi}}; {{lang-ber|Bernîk|script=Latn}}; also: ''Bengasi'',{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4462605&fid=3757&c=libya |title=Bengasi: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} ''Benghasi'',{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4462619&fid=3757&c=libya |title=Benghasi: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} ''Banghāzī'',{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4461835&fid=3757&c=libya |title=Banghāzī: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} ''Binghāzī'',{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4462912&fid=3766&c=libya |title=Binghāzī: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} ''Bengazi'';{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4462613&fid=3757&c=libya |title=Bengazi: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} {{lang-grc|Βερενίκη}} (''[[Berenice]]''){{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4462695&fid=3766&c=libya |title=Berenice: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}} and ''[[Hesperides]]''.{{cite web|url=http://geographic.org/geographic_names/name.php?uni=-4471792&fid=3771&c=libya |title=Hesperides: Libya |work=Geographical Names |accessdate=27 February 2011}}|group=note}} is the [[List of cities in Libya|second-most populous]] city in [[Libya]] and the largest in [[Cyrenaica]]. A port on the [[Mediterranean Sea]] in the Kingdom of Libya, Benghazi had joint-capital status alongside [[Tripoli]], possibly because the [[Idris I of Libya|King]] and the [[Senussi]] royal family were associated with Cyrenaica rather than [[Tripolitania]]. The city was also provisional capital of the [[National Transitional Council]].{{cite web | author = Staff | url= http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/libya-s-ex-justice-minister-forms-interim-government-in-benghazi-1.345892|title= Libya's Ex-Justice Minister Forms Interim Government in Benghazi – Former Libyan Minister Says Gadhafi 'Alone' Bore Responsibility for Crimes That Occurred, Qurnya Newspaper Reports |date = 26 February 2011|work= [[Haaretz]]|accessdate=13 September 2011}} Benghazi continues to hold institutions and organizations normally associated with a national capital city, such as the country's parliament, [[National Library of Libya|national library]], and the headquarters of [[Libyan Airlines]], the national airline, and of the [[National Oil Corporation]]. This creates a constant atmosphere of rivalry and sensitivities between Benghazi and Tripoli, and between Cyrenaica and Tripolitania. The population was 670,797 at the 2006 census.[http://www.spiegel.de/flash/flash-25431.html]. ''[[Der Spiegel]]''. 23 August 2011 On [[Timeline of the 2011 Libyan Civil War before military intervention#Early phase .2815.E2.80.9326 February.29|15 February 2011]],{{cite news|work=Al Jazeera|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/news/pages/ee1995da-6146-422c-91b5-c546d62999c2|title=بنغازي-صانعة-التاريخ-الليبي|date=2011-02-20}} [[First Battle of Benghazi|an uprising]] against the government of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] occurred in the city.{{cite news |url=http://www.indiancolleges.com/campus-stories/buzz//FB-and-Twitter-got-us-from-Tahrir-Square-to-Libya/339 |title=FB and Twitter Got Us from Tahrir Square to Libya|work=Benghazi After Gaddafi}} The revolts spread by 17 February to [[Bayda, Libya|Bayda]], [[Tobruk]], [[Ajdabya]], [[Al Marj]] in the East and [[Zintan]], [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]] in the West, calling for the end of the Gaddafi Regime. Benghazi was taken by Gaddafi opponents on 21 February, who founded the [[National Transitional Council]].{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 | publisher =BBC News | title=Japan Nuclear Crisis | date=26 March 2011}} On 19 March, the city was the site of the turning point of the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]], when the [[Libyan Army (1951–2011)|Libyan Army]] attempted to score a decisive victory against the NTC by [[Second Battle of Benghazi|attacking]] Benghazi, but was forced back by local resistance and intervention from the [[French Air Force]] authorized by [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973|UNSC Resolution 1973]] to protect civilians, allowing the rebellion to continue. == History == {{Main|History of Benghazi|Timeline of Benghazi}} === Ancient Greek colony === [[File:Panathenaic amphora Louvre MN705.jpg|thumb|A [[panathenaic amphora]] found in Benghazi from the times of ''Euesperides'', the ancient Greek city that is now Benghazi.]] The [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greek]] city that existed within the modern day boundaries of Benghazi was founded around 525 BC; at the time, it was called Euesperides. Euesperides was most likely founded by people from [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene]] or [[Barca (ancient city)|Barce]], which was located on the edge of a lagoon which opened from the sea. At the time, this area may have been deep enough to receive small sailing vessels. The name was attributed to the fertility of the neighborhood, which gave rise to the mythological associations of the garden of the [[Hesperides]]{{cite book | year = 2002| author = Ham, Anthony | publisher = [[Lonely Planet]] ([[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]]; [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]]) | title = Libya | page = 156 | isbn = 978-0-86442-699-4}} The ancient city existed on a raised piece of land opposite of what is now the Sidi-Abayd graveyard in the Northern Benghazi suburb of Sbikhat al-Salmani (al-Salmani [[Marsh]]). The city is first mentioned by ancient sources in [[Herodotus]]' account of the revolt of Barca and the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] expedition to [[Cyrenaica]] in c. 515 BC, where it is stated that the punitive force sent by the [[Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt|satrap of Egypt]] conquered Cyrenaica as far west as Euesperides.Herodotus, IV.204. The oldest coins minted in the city date back to 480 BC. One side of those coins has an engraving of Delphi. The other side is an engraving of a [[silphium]] plant, once the symbol of trade from Cyrenaica because of its use as a rich seasoning and as a medicine. The coinage suggests that the city must have enjoyed some autonomy from Cyrene in the early 5th century BC, when the issues of Euesperides had their own types with the legend EU(ES), distinct from those of Cyrene. The city was in hostile territory and was surrounded by inhospitable tribes. The Greek historian [[Thucydides]] mentions a siege of the city in 414 BC, by Libyans who were probably the Nasamones: Euesperides was saved by the unexpected arrival of the [[Sparta]]n general [[Gylippus]] and his fleet, who were blown to Libya by contrary winds on their way to [[Sicily]].{{cite book|author=Economou, Maria |date=August 1993| url=http://scholar.lib.vt.edu/ejournals/ElAnt/V1N4/economou.html |title=Euesperides: A Devastated Site| publisher=Digital Library and Archives, [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University]]|accessdate= 6 February 2009}} One of the Cyrenean kings whose fate is connected with the city is [[Arcesilaus IV of Cyrene|Arcesilaus IV]]. The king used his [[chariot]] victory at the [[Pythian Games]] of 462 BC to attract new settlers to Euesperides, where Arcesilaus hoped to create a safe refuge for himself against the resentment of the people of Cyrene. This proved ineffective, since when the king fled to Euesperides during the anticipated revolution (around 440 BC), he was assassinated, thus terminating the almost 200-year rule of the [[Battiadae|Battiad dynasty]]. An inscription found there and dated around the middle of the 4th century BC states that the city had a constitution similar to that of Cyrene, with a board of chief magistrates (''[[ephors]]'') and a council of elders (''gerontes''). Later in the 4th century BC, during the unsettled period which followed Alexander's death, the city backed the losing side in a revolt by the Spartan adventurer Thibron; trying to create an empire for himself, he was defeated by the Cyreneans and their allies. After the marriage around the middle of the 3rd century BC of [[Ptolemy III Euergetes|Ptolemy III]] to [[Berenice II|Berenice]], daughter of the Cyrenean [[Magas of Cyrene|Governor Magas]], many Cyrenaican cities were renamed to mark the occasion. ''Euesperides'' became '''''Berenice''''' and the change of name also involved a relocation. Its desertion was probably due to the [[silting]] up of the lagoons; Berenice, the place they moved to, lies underneath Benghazi's modern city centre. The Greek colony had lasted from the 6th to the mid-3rd centuries BC.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ===Romans and Christianity=== Modern Benghazi, on the [[Gulf of Sidra]], lies a little southwest of the site of the ancient Greek city of ''Berenice'' or ''Berenicis'' or ''Bernici''. That city was traditionally founded in 446 BC (different sources give different dates like 347 BC{{cite web |url=http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/dr_ibrahim_ighneiwa/benghc.htm |title=Libya: Benghazi; A Beautiful Libyan City |website=Ourworld |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224132315/http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/dr_ibrahim_ighneiwa/benghc.htm |archivedate=24 February 2009 |df=dmy }} or 249 BC{{cite web|website=Lexicorient.com|url=http://lexicorient.com/e.o/benghazi.htm| title= Benghazi}}), by a brother of the king of [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene]], but got the name Berenice only when it was refounded in the 3rd century BC under the patronage of [[Berenice II of Egypt|Berenice]] (''Berenike''), the daughter of [[Magas of Cyrene|Magas]], king of Cyrene, and wife of [[Ptolemy III of Egypt|Ptolemy III Euergetes]], the ruler of Egypt. The new city was later given the name '''''Hesperides''''', in reference to the [[Hesperides]], the guardians of the mythic western paradise. The name may have also referred to green [[Oasis|oases]] in low-lying areas in the nearby coastal plain. Benghazi later became a Roman city and greatly prospered for 600 years. The city superseded Cyrene and [[Barca (ancient city)|Barca]] as the chief center of Cyrenaica after the 3rd century AD and during the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] attacks; in 642–643 -when was conquered by the Arabs and partially destroyed- it had dwindled to an insignificant village among magnificent historic ruins.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In its more prosperous period, Berenice became a [[Christianity|Christian]] [[bishopric]]. The first of its bishops whose name is recorded in extant documents is Ammon, to whom [[Dionysius of Alexandria]] wrote in about 260. Dathes was at the [[First Council of Nicaea]] in 325, and Probatius at a synod held in [[Constantinople]] in 394.Michel Lequien, [https://books.google.com/books?id=86weAemI-e4C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Oriens christianus in quatuor Patriarchatus digestus''], Paris 1740, Vol. II, coll. 623-626Pius Bonifacius Gams, [http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/doccontent?id=65154&dirids=1 ''Series episcoporum Ecclesiae Catholicae''], Leipzig 1931, p. 462 No longer a residential bishopric, Berenice is today listed by the [[Catholic Church]] as a [[titular see]].''Annuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana 2013 {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), p. 838 [[File:Mawlid Celebrations in Ottoman Benghazi.jpg|thumb|right|The Ottoman flag is raised during Mawlid celebrations in Benghazi in 1896.]] === Ottoman province === In the 13th century, the small settlement became an important player in the trade growing up between Genoese merchants and the tribes of the hinterland. In 16th century maps, the name of '''''Marsa ibn Ghazi''''' appears.{{clarify|date=September 2011|reason=It appears that an entire period, called "The Arabs and the Advent of Islam" in 'History of Benghazi' article, is missing from this article. During that period, appears to have happened the name change from "Berenice" (or "Hesperides") to "Barneeq".}} Benghazi had a strategic port location, one that was too useful to be ignored by the Ottomans. In 1578, the Turks invaded Benghazi and it was ruled from Tripoli by the [[Karamanli dynasty|Karamanlis]] from 1711 to 1835; it then passed under direct [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] rule until 1911. Greek and [[Italy|Italian]] sponge fishermen worked its coastal waters. In 1858, and again in 1874, Benghazi was devastated by [[bubonic plague]]. === Italian colonial rule === {{Main|Italian Benghazi}} [[File:Italian Benghazi.jpg|thumb|The colonial Italians created the "Lungomare" (sea-walk) of Benghazi and constructed many other buildings]] [[File:Cyrenaica Parliament.jpg|thumb|Littorio Palace in Benghazi was the seat of the Cyrenaican regional assembly]] In 1911, Benghazi was invaded and conquered by the Italians. Nearly half the local population of Cyrenaica under the leadership of [[Omar Mukhtar]] resisted the Italian occupation.Cyrenaica suffered oppression, particularly under the fascist dictator [[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini]]. About 125,000 Libyans were forced into concentration camps, about one-third of whom perished (mainly because of epidemics) In the early 1930s, the revolt was over and the Italians—under governor [[Italo Balbo]]—started attempts to assimilate the local population with pacifying policies: a number of new villages for Cyrenaicans were created with health services and schools. Additionally Cyrenaica was populated by more than 20,000 [[Italian settlers in Libya|Italian colonists]] in the late 1930s, mainly around the coast of Benghazi. Benghazi population was made up of more than 35 per cent of Italians in 1939[http://dadfeatured.blogspot.com/2018/09/bengasi-italiana.html "Bengasi Italiana"]. As a consequence, there was in Cyrenaica and mostly in Benghazi a huge economic development in the second half of the 1930s. Benghazi grew to be a modern city with a new airport, new railways station, new seaplane station, an enlarged port and many facilities. Benghazi was going to be connected in 1940 by a new railway to Tripoli, but in summer of that year war started between Italians and British and infrastructure development came to a standstill. === World War II === During [[Operation Compass]] in [[World War II]], Benghazi was captured from the Italians by [[Combe Force]] on 6 February 1941. It was recaptured by [[Axis powers]], led by general [[Erwin Rommel]] of the [[Afrika Korps|German Africa Corps]], on 4 April.Keegan, John. ''Atlas of World War II''. Harper Collins Publishers, 2006, p.62 l.4 It was taken again during [[Operation Crusader]] by the British on 24 December only to change hands again on 29 January 1942 in the Rommel Afrika Corp's push to Egypt. During the fateful [[Second Battle of El Alamein|Battle of El Alamein]]–{{convert|106|km|abbr=off}} from [[Alexandria]], Egypt–British troops led by general [[Bernard Montgomery]] again defeated the Africa Corps which then made a long steady retreat westward passing through Benghazi for the final time. On 20 November, Benghazi was captured by the [[Eighth Army (United Kingdom)|British Eighth Army]] and thereafter held by the British. === Contemporary Benghazi === [[File:Piazza del Shagara Bengasi 1964.jpg|thumb|left|[[Maydan al-Shajara]], in central Benghazi in 1964]] Heavily bombed in [[World War II]], Benghazi was later rebuilt with the country's newly found oil wealth as a gleaming showpiece of [[History of Modern Libya|modern Libya]]. It became the capital city of [[Emirate of Cyrenaica]] (1949–1951) under [[Idris of Libya|Idris Senussi I]]. In 1951, Cyrenaica was merged with Tripolitania and Fezzan to form the independent [[Kingdom of Libya]], of which both Benghazi and Tripoli were capital cities. [[File:King Idris I of Libya.png|thumb|Support for the Senussi dynasty remained strong in Cyrenaica]] Benghazi lost its capital status when the Free Officers under the leadership of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] staged a ''coup d'état'' in 1969, whereafter all government institutions were concentrated in Tripoli, Even though King Idris was forced into exile and the monarchy abolished, support for the Senussi dynasty remained strong in Cyrenaica. This was emphasized by real or perceived injustices from the government towards the people of Benghazi, including the demolition in the year 2000 of the arena of [[association football|football]] club [[Alahly Benghazi S.C.]], following anti-government protests.{{cite news| author=McDonnell, Patrick J. |date= 21 May 2011|url= http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/opinion/fyi/political-football-benghazi-style-122381063.html?device=mobile |title=Political Football, Benghazi Style – Soccer Club, Fans Found You Don't Mess with Gadhafi|work= [[Winnipeg Free Press]]|accessdate= 13 September 2011}}{{cite news|author=Lubin, Gus |date=18 July 2011| url= http://www.businessinsider.com/benghazi-soccer-resistance-2011-7#ixzz1SURrR4YKFlag| title=An Amazing Story Of Resistance From Inside Libya's Soccer League|work= [[Business Insider]]}} [[File:Gaddafi 1972.jpg|thumb|Colonel [[Muammar Gaddafi|Gaddafi]] abolished the Monarchy in Libya]] On 15 April 1986, U.S. Air Force and Navy planes [[1986 Bombing of Libya|bombed Benghazi and Tripoli.]] President [[Ronald Reagan]] justified the attacks by claiming Libya was responsible for terrorism directed at the United States, including the [[1986 Berlin discotheque bombing|bombing of La Belle discothèque in West Berlin]] ten days before.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} === 2011 Revolution === {{main|First Battle of Benghazi|Second Battle of Benghazi}} [[File:Bengasi court square 0824b.jpg|thumb|right|Court square in Benghazi, April 2011. At the central place for gatherings and demonstrations the walls are draped with pictures of casualties, mourners passing by.]] [[File:Benghazi Anti-Qaddafi protest.jpg|thumb|left|A large crowd of anti-Gaddafi protesters from in and around Benghazi took to the streets on 6 July 2011, amassing in front of the Kateba and the courtyard.]] In February 2011, peaceful protests erupted in Benghazi that were brutally suppressed by Gaddafi's armed kalb forces and loyalists. The violence urged the people to fight back and start and uprise to withdraw Gaddafi from power [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|The Libyan Revolution]]. At least 500 people were killed in the protests against the government.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/gaddafi-fights-for-his-future-as-up-to-200-die-in-benghazi-2220131.html | title = Gaddafi: What Now for Libya's Dictator, and Where Does Britain Stand? – As rebellion Spreads, Tripoli's Hardline Regime Cracks Down, Killing at Least 100 Protesters and Leaving 1,000 Injured | work=[[The Independent]] |author1=Johnson, Andrew |author2=Mesure, Susie | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate =13 September 2011}} [[File:A Benghazi citizen holding King Idris's photo.JPG|thumb|A young Benghazian carrying (deposed) King Idris' photo. Support of the [[Senussi|Senussi dynasty]] has traditionally been strong in [[Cyrenaica]].{{cite web|title=Who should govern Britain?|url=https://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21650113-despite-risk-europe-coalition-led-david-cameron-should-have-second-term-who|website=Economist.com|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=11 May 2015}}]] The former [[Flag of Libya|Libyan flag]] used in the [[Kingdom of Libya]] was used by many protesters as an [[Libyan opposition|opposition]] flag.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/world/article24612799.html |title=Violent Repression of Protests Rocks Libya, Bahrain, Yemen |last=Landay, Janathan S. |last2=Strobel, Warren P. |date=18 February 2011 |website=McClatchy DC |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111084330/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/world/article24612799.html |archive-date=11 November 2016 |access-date=19 February 2011 |last3=Ibrahim, Arwa}}{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2011/feb/17/bahrain-crisis-middle-east-protests-live-blog#block-20|title= Bahrain in Crisis and Middle East Protests – Live Blog|author= Tran, Mark|date= 17 February 2011|work= [[The Guardian]] | accessdate=19 February 2011}} Demonstrators to Colonel Gaddafi were also seen carrying images of King Idris I. Benghazi and the [[Cyrenaica]] have been traditional strongholds of the royal [[Senussi]] dynasty.{{Cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/18239900 |title=The Liberated East: Building a New Libya |date=24 February 2011 |work=[[The Economist]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227092930/http://www.economist.com/node/18239900 |archive-date=27 February 2011 |access-date=26 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} As of 21 February, the city was reported to be largely controlled by the opposition. The widely loathed mayor, [[Huda Ben Amer]], nicknamed "the Executioner", fled the city for Tripoli.{{cite news| author = Meo, Nick|title='Huda the Executioner' – Libya's Devil in Female Form – How Pulling on a Hanging Man's Legs Made Huda Ben Amer One of Colonel Gaddafi's Most Trusted Elite |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8363587/Huda-the-executioner-Libyas-devil-in-female-form.html|accessdate=13 September 2011| work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] |date= 6 March 2011}} Residents organised to direct traffic and collect refuse. By 24 February, a committee made up of lawyers, judges and respected local people had been formed in order to provide civic administration and public services within the city. Two local radio stations, operated by [[Voice of Free Libya]], along with a newspaper, were also established.Staff (24 February 2011). [http://feb17.info/media/first-edition-of-the-benghazi-newspaper/ "First Edition of the Benghazi Newspaper"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301030122/http://feb17.info/media/first-edition-of-the-benghazi-newspaper/ |date=1 March 2011 }}. feb17.info. Retrieved 13 September 2011. From 26 February to 26 August, Benghazi was the temporary headquarters of the [[National Transitional Council]] which is led by the former justice minister, [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]], until Tripoli was liberated. On 19 March, pro-Gaddafi forces almost defeated the rebellion when they began attacking the city of Benghazi in a major [[Second Battle of Benghazi|offensive]], but were forced back the next day when NATO forces began implementing [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973]].Staff (19 March 2011). [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/03/2011319132058782326.html "French Jets Attack Gaddafi Targets – Warplanes Destroy Four Tanks Used by Libyan Leader's Army as Military Action To Enforce UN-Ordered No-Fly Zone Begins"]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. Retrieved 13 September 2011. On 1 June, explosives were detonated in a car near the [[Tibesti Hotel]],Staff (1 June 2011). [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13622805 "Libya: Benghazi Blast Rocks Hotel Used by Rebels – Jalal il Gallal, National Transitional Council: 'It Was a Cowardly Act'"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 13 September 2011. with a rebel spokesman calling the bombing a "cowardly act". It was suspected that an officer was killed, and many people started to shout out anti-Gaddafi chants while the Tibesti was cordoned off. On 19 May 2012, residents of Benghazi voted in historic [[Benghazi municipal election, 2012|local elections]]; this was the first time such elections have been held in the city since the 1960s, and turnout was high. === 2012 attack on U.S. diplomatic mission === {{Main|2012 Benghazi attack}} On 11 September 2012, the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi was attacked by a heavily armed group of 125–150 gunmen, whose trucks bore the logo of [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]], a group of Islamist militants, also known as Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula,[[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] working with the local government to manage security in Benghazi.{{Cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/libyan-witnesses-recount-organized-benghazi-attack |title=Libyan witnesses recount organized Benghazi attack |last=Paul Shemm |date=2012-10-27 |work=Associated Press |last2=Maggie Michael |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030013039/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/libyan-witnesses-recount-organized-benghazi-attack |archive-date=2012-10-30 |last-author-amp=yes |access-date=2012-10-27}} U.S. Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]], Foreign Service Information Management Officer (IMO) [[Sean Smith (diplomat)|Sean Smith]], and CIA contractors and former Navy SEALS Tyrone Woods and Glen Doherty were killed during a series of raids, commencing at nightfall and continuing into the next morning. Ten others were injured. === Second Libyan Civil War === {{main|Battle of Benghazi (2014–2017)}} Following the outbreak of the [[Libyan Civil War (2014–present)|second Libyan Civil War]] in 2014, Benghazi became the subject of heavy fighting between the [[Libyan National Army]]-aligned [[House of Representatives (Libya)|House of Representatives]] government, and the Islamist [[Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries]] and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]]-aligned [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in Libya|Wilayat Barqa]], which were entrenched in various pockets in the city. During the closing months of the battle, between late-2016 and mid-2017, much of the urban center in and around the remaining Shura Council pocket in the central coastal quarters of Suq Al-Hout and al-Sabri suffered heavy bombardment and war damage. Wilayat Barqa militants reportedly fled Benghazi in early January, while the LNA's General [[Khalifa Haftar]] declared the city cleared of the Shura Council on 5 July 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/haftar-forces-declare-victory-battle-benghazi-170705231914703.html|title=Haftar's forces declare victory in battle for Benghazi|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=5 July 2017}} Despite Haftar's declaration of the liberation of the city, dozens of gunmen remained fortified and besieged in Sidi Akribesh, according to sources close to military.{{cite news|url=https://aawsat.com/english/home/article/1096186/asharq-al-awsat-tours-extremist-dens-libya-story-sidi-khreibish|title=Asharq Al-Awsat Tours Extremist Dens in Libya: The Story of Sidi Khreibish|publisher=Asharq al-Awsat}} LNA captured the last militant-held district in December 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-12/29/c_136858201.htm|title=Libyan army takes over remaining militant stronghold in Benghazi|work=Xinhua News Agency}} == Administrative divisions == [[File:Benghazi Mu'tamarat Sha'bia.jpg|thumb|right|400px|There are 32 Mu'tamarat Sha'bia in the District of Benghazi.]] [[File:Libyen Benghazi.png|thumb|left|100px|Benghazi district between 2001 and 2007.]] [[File:Shabiat Banghazi since 2007.png|thumb|left|100px|Benghazi district since 2007.]] Benghazi is one of Libya's 22 [[shabiyah]]s (people's districts). Benghazi Baladiyat is divided into 32 [[Basic People's Congress (country subdivision)|Basic People's Congress]] administrative divisions, in which the responsibilities of the corresponding political units of the same name fall. The official 32 Basic People's Congresses of Benghazi are:{{dead link|date=September 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://gpco.gov.ly/online/shabyat.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220214410/http://gpco.gov.ly/online/shabyat.php |archivedate=20 December 2008 |df=dmy }}. {| border="0" |- |

32 [[Al-Hadaa'iq]] |} == Population == === Demographics === {{refimprove|date=September 2011}} [[File:Benghazi. Omar Mukhtar Street.jpg|thumb|right|Omar Al Mukhtar Street in the Italian quarter was traditionally home to an urbane demographic, before many families left the old town to resettle elsewhere in the city.]] As with other cities in Libya, there is a reasonable amount of ethnic diversity in Benghazi. The people of eastern Libya, Benghazi included, have in the past always been of predominantly [[Berbers|Berber]] descent. In recent times, however, there has been an influx of [[Africa]]n immigrants into Benghazi. There are also many [[Egypt]]ian immigrants in Benghazi. A small [[Greek people|Greek]] community also exists in Benghazi. The [[Greece|Greek]] island of [[Crete]] is a short distance from Benghazi and many families in Benghazi today bear Cretan surnames. There are even a few [[Italian people|Italian]]-related families, left from the colonial times before [[World War II]]. The overwhelming majority of Libyans in Benghazi are of Berber descent, though there is a minority of [[Arab people|Arab descent]]. In the 11th century, the [[Sa'ada]] tribe from the [[Bani Salim]] migrated to Cyrenaica; each sub tribe from the Sa'adi historically controlled a section of Cyrenaica. Benghazi and its surrounding areas were controlled by [[Barghathi]] tribe. In modern times, Benghazi has seen a lot of Libyans from different parts of the country move into the city, especially since the Kingdom era. Many came to Benghazi from [[Misrata]]. Thus Benghazi has always been seen as a welcoming city, a city which the local Bedouins refer to as 'Benghazi rabayit al thayih' which can be translated as, 'Benghazi raises the lost' as many immigrants who arrived from the Western Maghreb or the former Al Andalus came with little money, clothes or food and were looked after very generously by the local Bedouin population as well as those arriving following the Italian war from western Libya. === Religion === [[File:Maydan al Baladiya.jpg|thumb|left|The Atiq Mosque in Maydan al-Baladiya is the oldest mosque in Benghazi. The majority of people in the city are Sunni Muslims.]] The predominant religion in Benghazi is [[Islam]]. Practically all of the city's inhabitants are [[Sunni]] Muslims. During Islamic holidays such as Ramadan, most abstain from food; restaurants are usually empty during the day, with the exception of some expatriates and tourists. Alcohol is banned by law in Benghazi and throughout Libya in accordance with Islamic principles. The conservative Islamic nature of Benghazi creates a strong sense of family life in the city – practically all teenagers and young adults live at home until they get married. Many Muslims in Benghazi adhere to the traditional [[Maliki]] school of religious law, however much less so than in decades past. In recent years, more people are beginning to practice [[Salafism]] with the spread of literalist inclined Islamic television channels. It is not uncommon therefore to see woman wearing black [[niqab]]s and men with full beards in Benghazi because of the existence of such schools, although not exclusively for that purpose.{{Cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/future-shock |title=Future shock |last=Athanasiadis |first=Iason |publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |publication-date=29 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111085704/http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/future-shock |archive-date=2016-11-11 |access-date=6 September 2010 }}Athanasiadis, Iason (29 May 2009). [http://www.thenational.ae/article/20090529/REVIEW/705289979/1008 "Future Shock"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530105107/http://www.thenational.ae/article/20090529/REVIEW/705289979/1008 |date=30 May 2009 }}. ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]''. Retrieved 6 September 2010. The [[Senussi]] order from which the royal dynasty sprang has traditionally enjoyed strong support in Benghazi and the Cyrenaica. For Muslims, there are many mosques throughout Benghazi; the oldest and best known such as the [[Atiq Mosque (Benghazi)|Atiq]] and Osman mosques are located in and around the [[Medina quarter|medina]]. There is also a small Christian community in the city. The Roman Catholic [[Apostolic Vicariate of Benghazi]]'s Franciscan Church of the Immaculate Conception serves Benghazi's Latin Catholic community of roughly 4,000; there is also a decommossioned [[Benghazi Cathedral|cathedral church]] (1929-1939; closed 1977; under restoration since 2009). For [[Copt|Egyptian Copts]], there is a [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox]] church (which was formerly the grand synagogue) with two serving [[priest]]s.Shefler, Gil (13 August 2010). [http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=184634 "Haddad Story Highlights Efforts To Recover Libyan Assets"]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Retrieved 13 September 2011. [[The Jewish Community of Benghazi|Jews lived in Benghazi]] as [[History of the Jews in Libya|they did elsewhere in Libya]], from Roman times until 1967 when most were airlifted out after a series of riots in the years after the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]]. There are no Jews remaining in Libya today.{{cite web| author = Deming, Mark | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/392157/The-Last-Jews-of-Libya/overview | publisher = [[Rovi Corporation]]|work=[[The New York Times]] | title= The Last Jews of Libya (2007) | accessdate =13 September 2011}} === Education === {{unreferenced section|date=September 2011}} [[File:General Peoples Congress Benghazi.jpg|thumb|Al Manar Royal Palace in central Benghazi, [[University of Libya]]'s first campus, founded by royal decree in 1955]] The oldest university in Libya is the [[University of Libya]], founded by royal decree in 1955. It was initially housed in the royal Al Manar Palace before receiving its own campus in 1968. It was later split and became known as [[University of Benghazi]]. There are some private universities such as [[Libyan International Medical University]]. Education in Benghazi, as is throughout Libya, is compulsory and free. Compulsory education continues up until [[ninth grade]]. There are many public primary and secondary schools scattered throughout the city as well as some private schools. University education is also free for all Libyan citizens in Benghazi. There are many other foreign schools such as [[Benghazi European School]] & private schools but G.International is the best for the wards. The country's largest library containing over 300,000 volumes is affiliated with the university. International schools include: * [[International School Benghazi]] * [[Benghazi European School]] * [[British School in Benghazi]] == Geography == {{unreferenced section|date=September 2011}} [[File:Benghazi 20.08955E 32.10942N.jpg|thumb|Satellite image of Benghazi]] Benghazi is one of the sub-regions of the area referred to as [[Cyrenaica]], the others being the [[Jebel Akhdar, Libya|Jebel Akhdar]] and the coastal plain running east of [[Apollonia, Cyrenaica|Apollonia]]. Cyrenaica is surrounded by desert on three sides, hence in ancient times the most accessible civilisation was to the North, across the Mediterranean, in [[Crete]] and [[Greece]], only {{convert|400|km|abbr=off}} away. Benghazi is surrounded by the "barr", arid [[steppe]]. The Jebel Akhdar, literally, "the Green Mountain", just north of Benghazi, rises to the east. Here the vegetation and climate is more Mediterranean in feel with none of the desert landscapes found further south. A large section of the western Jebel Akhdar is taken up by the fertile Marj plain. Further east is the second level of the Jebel Akhdar, between {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=off}} and over {{convert|875|m|ft|abbr=on}} above sea level, often thickly wooded and cut by [[Canyon|ravines]]. Annual rainfall here, especially around Cyrene, can reach {{convert|500|mm|in|abbr=off}}. It was this fertile site northeast of Benghazi that the Greeks chose for their settlement. The soil in Benghazi is a rich red colour and very [[clay]]ey. [[Sirocco]] winds are not uncommon in the city, and as such, many of Benghazi's smaller streets and buildings can be quite dusty. To the north, below the steep cliffs of the [[plateau]], lies a narrow belt of Mediterranean farmland. Olives and other mediterranean fruits and vegetables are grown here. To the south, the forest and farmland gives way to juniper bush [[Maquis shrubland|maquis]] and pre-desert scrub with some winter grazing. As a [[Districts of Libya|district]], Benghazi borders [[Hizam Al Akhdar]], which surrounds it on land. === Natural recreation and parks === {{unreferenced section|date=September 2011}} [[File:Bodzeera.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Al-Buduzeera is one of the largest and most popular parks in Benghazi.]] Although Benghazi does not have a high percentage of green space per resident, there are a few public parks and green recreational areas in the city. Perhaps the most famous is the zoological garden and theme park in Al-Fuwayhat; the park is referred to locally as ''al-Bosco'', a colloquial Italian name for zoo/forest. The park is a combination of a zoo full of trees built during Italian rule (which contains wild cats, primates, elephants, birds and other animals) and a small theme park of electric rides, added later in the 1980s as part of a redevelopment of the entire site. It is one of the most popular parks in Benghazi, and is very busy on public holidays, as well as amongst school children and [[Public Scout and Girl Guide Movement|scouts]] on outings. On Gamal Abdel Nasser Street is 23 July Park, another large green space which faces the Tibesti Hotel and borders the waterfront. The park is popular amongst teenagers, and families on Thursday nights (as Friday is a day off work throughout Libya). Another large and popular park is al-Buduzira in North Benghazi on the al-'Uruba Road in al-Kwayfiya. The park surrounds a natural lake, and is more rugged in nature than the city parks. A section of al-Buduzira is also a water park with large slides, whilst the southern part of the park has picnic areas which are popular in the summers. === Climate === Benghazi has a warm [[semi-arid climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''BSh''). In the north of the city lies the Mediterranean-climate 'Jabal Al-Akhdar' (Green Mountains), and in the south the climate is becoming desert-like. Summers in Benghazi are hot and rainless, but with high levels of humidity. Winters are mild with occasional rain. Annual rainfall is low at {{convert|270|mm|in|abbr=on}} per year. The city's local water supply is supplemented by groundwater transported from the aquifers of southern Libya along the [[Great Manmade River]]. {{Weather box |location = Benghazi ([[Benina
